messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: Yari and Naginata
messages.msgSnippet: Right on Andres,                                  Keep me posted.  Best to you and all out there this holiday season.   Mark
messages.messageBody:
Right on Andres,
                                 Keep me posted.  Best to you and all out
there this holiday season.
 
Mark
 

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
Behalf Of Andres Pedraza
Sent: Friday, December 22, 2006 9:56 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Yari and Naginata



Mark,

I will keep an eye out for them. I support IT for 3 companies
through my employer, one of the top 3 global outsourcers. One of my
accounts happens to be in the publishing world, books and media.
I'll see if I can ferret the tapes out through them next year.

Best Regards,

Andres

"mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com"nihontostudy@-yahoogroups.-com, "Mark

Mark,

I will keep an eye out for them. I support IT for 3 companies
through my employer, one of the top 3 global outsourcers. One of my
accounts happens to be in the publishing world, books and media.
I'll see if I can ferret the tapes out through them next year.

Best Regards,

Andres

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Yari and Naginata
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Andres,                       Just came across information on two tapes on Naginata by Helen Nakano Sensei. All I know is that they re
messages.messageBody:
Hi Andres,
��������������������� Just came across information on two tapes on Naginata
by Helen Nakano Sensei. All I know is that they're in existence. If you find
out any information on them, please let me know.
�
Mark
�

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
Behalf Of Andres Pedraza
Sent: Friday, December 08, 2006 1:34 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Yari and Naginata



Mark,

Thanks for the info on Kendo World and the Naginata book. I'll look
into it. I am a "practitioner"-, although the weapon I mostly train
with is the katana. Nonetheless, I started training with naginata,
too, about, oh, 3 years ago. I'm still a rank beginner, but I'm very
much interested in it as a weapon. I also started training in Yari
around the same time. But while I practice and learn katana waza
weekly, or sometimes more often, I do naginata and yari maybe once a month.

Best Regards,

Andres

At 07:54 AM 12/8/2006, you wrote:
>Hi Andres,
> Nice to see someone else out there interested in these
>wonderful polearms. Knutsen's book is one of the only ones in english that
I
>am aware of. Are you a "practitioner" of Naginata or simply looking to
study
>them?
>Another book you may want to look at is; Naginata - The Definitive Guide by
>Dr. Alexander Bennett. It is only available through;
>HYPERLINK " HYPERLINK
"http://www.kendo-world.com"http://www.kendo--world.com"www.kendo-world.-com
A warning
>though; the suppliers have a "reputation" for being slow with their orders.
>I placed an order 2 weeks ago and there hasn't been any movement on my
>credit card or even an e-mail confirmation of my request. Expect a wait of
>3-4 months! With that said, the book comes with some glowing reviews since
>anything on the subject in english is so rare. During the historical
>developement of Japan, it's amazing to see that the Katana took a backseat
>to the Bow and Naginata.
>
>Mark
>
>
>
>-----Original Message-----
>From: HYPERLINK
"mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com"nihontostudy@-yahoogroups.-com
[mailto: HYPERLINK
"mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com"nihontostudy@-yahoogroups.-com]On
>Behalf Of Andres Pedraza
>Sent: Thursday, December 07, 2006 8:43 PM
>To: HYPERLINK "mailto:nihonto%40yahoogroups.com"nihonto@...;
HYPERLINK
"mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com"nihontostudy@-yahoogroups.-com
>Subject: [nihontostudy] Yari and Naginata
>
>
>
>Nihonto People,
>
>I haven't seen a whole lot of books on Yari and/or Naginata in
>English, so even though it was a bit pricy, I purchased Roald and
>Susan Knutsen's book ( HYPERLINK
>" HYPERLINK "http://tinyurl.com/yxlhuj"http://tinyurl.-com/yxlhuj"
HYPERLINK "http://tinyurl.-com/yxlhuj"http://tinyurl.--com/yxlhuj). I just
finished it.
>I am very impressed and sorry I did not purchase it earlier. The
>concise yet informative text plus the wealth of drawings and plates
>was well worth the price.
>
>If there's anyone else out there interested in the subject and that
>has been on the fence about this great book because of the price tag,
>well, stop considering it and buy it. Give it to yourself for
>Christmas. You won't regret it.
>
>And if Roald and Susan subscribe to these lists (or someone who knows
>them does) please receive a big thank you from me... This book will
>be a permanent part of my reference library.
>
>Anyone have any other books on Yari and/or Naginata they want to
>recommend? I'm thirsty for more knowledge now.
>
>Thanks!
>
>Andres
>

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Yari and Naginata
messages.msgSnippet: G day Barry,                       No rush but if you come across that information, by all means please pass it along.   Kind regards,
messages.messageBody:
G'day Barry,
��������������������� No rush but if you come across that information, by
all means please pass it along.
�
Kind regards, Mark
�

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
Behalf Of Barry Thomas
Sent: Friday, December 08, 2006 7:07 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Yari and Naginata



Mark and all,
There is a lady on one of our lists who is a naginata exponent. This is from
the dim, dark, dusty bin of my memory, but I think her name is Carol
Horvath. She and I have exchanged naginata related emails and I have all
this on another hard disk drive. If it matters I can dig deeply into my hard
disk drive archive and find her email address and website details, and of
course her dojo.

Best regards,

Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: Mark Jaillet
To: HYPERLINK
"mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com"nihontostudy@-yahoogroups.-com
Sent: Saturday, December 09, 2006 4:53 AM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Yari and Naginata

Ron,
Do you happen to know what Dojo they'd be from? I couldn't find
anything from Chicago under the United States Naginata Federation.

Mark


-----Original Message-----
From: HYPERLINK
"mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com"nihontostudy@-yahoogroups.-com
[mailto: HYPERLINK
"mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com"nihontostudy@-yahoogroups.-com]On
Behalf Of Ron Hartmann
Sent: Friday, December 08, 2006 1:41 PM
To: HYPERLINK
"mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com"nihontostudy@-yahoogroups.-com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Yari and Naginata

Andres -

A number of years back a group of women from the Chicago area put on an
absolutely awesome demonstration of naginata usage, the first (and last)
I've ever experienced. It would be an interesting demonstration to again
present at one of our sword shows particularly for us non-martial arts guys
and gals.

Ron
STL
.

messages.subject: Re: Yari and Naginata
messages.msgSnippet: ... seem to recall that Saul Ploplys wife was in that group...but it has been a few years ago. Milt, do you know?? ... I tends to avoid ladies with sharp
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Ron Hartmann" <swords@...> wrote:
>
> No, I've no idea but perhaps one of the Chicago guys would know. I
seem to recall that Saul Ploplys wife was in that group...but it has
been a few years ago. Milt, do you know??
>
> Ron

I tends to avoid ladies with sharp things..............
If Ole Saul's boss plays with the naginata then it explains a lot of
Saul's behavior.
Perhaps the best person to ask is Big George of Wisconsin.

milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Yari and Naginata
messages.msgSnippet: Mark and all, There is a lady on one of our lists who is a naginata exponent.  This is from the dim, dark, dusty bin of my memory, but I think her name is
messages.messageBody:
Mark and all,
There is a lady on one of our lists who is a naginata exponent. This is from the dim, dark, dusty bin of my memory, but I think her name is Carol Horvath. She and I have exchanged naginata related emails and I have all this on another hard disk drive. If it matters I can dig deeply into my hard disk drive archive and find her email address and website details, and of course her dojo.

Best regards,

Barry Thomas.

messages.messageBody:
No, I've no idea but perhaps one of the Chicago guys would know. I seem to recall that Saul Ploplys wife was in that group...but it has been a few years ago. Milt, do you know??

Ron
STL

Mark,

Thanks for the info on Kendo World and the Naginata book. I'll look
into it. I am a "practitioner"-, although the weapon I mostly train
with is the katana. Nonetheless, I started training with naginata,

much interested in it as a weapon. I also started training in Yari
around the same time. But while I practice and learn katana waza
weekly, or sometimes more often, I do naginata and yari maybe once a month.

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Yari and Naginata
messages.msgSnippet: Ron,            Do you happen to know what Dojo they d be from?  I couldn t find anything from Chicago under the United States Naginata Federation.
messages.messageBody:
Ron,
           Do you happen to know what Dojo they'd be from?  I couldn't find
anything from Chicago under the United States Naginata Federation.
 
Mark
 

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
Behalf Of Ron Hartmann
Sent: Friday, December 08, 2006 1:41 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Yari and Naginata



Andres -

A number of years back a group of women from the Chicago area put on an
absolutely awesome demonstration of naginata usage, the first (and last)
I've ever experienced. It would be an interesting demonstration to again
present at one of our sword shows particularly for us non-martial arts guys
and gals.

Ron
STL

----- Original Message -----
From: Andres Pedraza
To: HYPERLINK
"mailto:nihontostudy%40yahoogroups.com"nihontostudy@-yahoogroups.-com
Sent: Friday, December 08, 2006 11:33 AM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Yari and Naginata

Mark,

Thanks for the info on Kendo World and the Naginata book. I'll look
into it. I am a "practitioner"-, although the weapon I mostly train
with is the katana. Nonetheless, I started training with naginata,
too, about, oh, 3 years ago. I'm still a rank beginner, but I'm very
much interested in it as a weapon. I also started training in Yari
around the same time. But while I practice and learn katana waza
weekly, or sometimes more often, I do naginata and yari maybe once a month.

Best Regards,

Andres

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Yari and Naginata
messages.msgSnippet: Just ordered a copy. Thanks for the heads-up Andres. Yes, I have considered that book whenever it came to mind but being a procrastinator...so now it s done!
messages.messageBody:
Just ordered a copy. Thanks for the heads-up Andres. Yes, I have considered that book whenever it came to mind but being a procrastinator...so now it's done! (Old guys need a push sometimes!)

Back in the '80s Roland Knutsen wrote an article on polearms for the JSS/US Newsletter. I'll have to dig that out and have look at it again; if so, I'll pass on the issue number for those interested (who have back issues). I could never forget the article because he submitted in in longhand and being unfamiliar with many of the terms he used, it was a bear to type up (before computers) for that issue. Drove me nuts, but I was thrilled to have the material. Again, I'll try to find out when this was done and will pass that info on.

Ron
STL



----- Original Message -----
From: Andres Pedraza
To: nihonto@yahoogroups.com ; nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, December 07, 2006 6:43 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Yari and Naginata


Nihonto People,

I haven't seen a whole lot of books on Yari and/or Naginata in
English, so even though it was a bit pricy, I purchased Roald and
Susan Knutsen's book (http://tinyurl.com/yxlhuj). I just finished it.
I am very impressed and sorry I did not purchase it earlier. The
concise yet informative text plus the wealth of drawings and plates
was well worth the price.

If there's anyone else out there interested in the subject and that
has been on the fence about this great book because of the price tag,
well, stop considering it and buy it. Give it to yourself for
Christmas. You won't regret it.

And if Roald and Susan subscribe to these lists (or someone who knows
them does) please receive a big thank you from me... This book will
be a permanent part of my reference library.

Anyone have any other books on Yari and/or Naginata they want to
recommend? I'm thirsty for more knowledge now.

Thanks!

Andres

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]





[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: Yari and Naginata
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Mark, Pole arms have always been synonymous with defense against cavalry throughout history and throughout the world. It is amazing how similar weapons and
messages.messageBody:
Hi Mark, Pole arms have always been synonymous with defense against
cavalry throughout history and throughout the world. It is amazing
how similar weapons and strategies develop as a result of similar
necessities. Anyhow, with the development of the teppo and the
greater use of ashigaru in melee use of the pole arm declined,
however it never disappeared as a strategic weapon against cavalry.
If I recall correctly even during the American civil war there were
troops of billmen to repulse cavalry attack. The spear in many
cultures was the primary weapon as was the yari on early
battlefields. Again surviving until the 19th century including for
example the various mounted lancers brigades. Polearms are a vital
part of Japanese history and can't be ignored, these books help. John

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Yari and Naginata
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Andres,                       Nice to see someone else out there interested in these wonderful polearms. Knutsen s book is one of the
messages.messageBody:
Hi Andres,
��������������������� Nice to see someone else out there interested in�these
wonderful polearms. Knutsen's book is one of the only ones in english that I
am aware of. Are you a "practitioner" of Naginata or simply looking to study
them?
Another book you may want to look at is; Naginata - The Definitive Guide by
Dr. Alexander Bennett.� It is only available through;
HYPERLINK "http://www.kendo-world.com"www.kendo-world.com���� A warning
though; the suppliers have a "reputation" for being slow with their orders.
I placed an order 2 weeks ago and there hasn't been any movement on my
credit card or even an e-mail confirmation of my request.� Expect a wait of
3-4 months! With that said, the book comes with some glowing reviews since
anything on the subject in english is so rare. During the historical
developement of Japan, it's amazing to see that the Katana took a backseat
to the Bow and Naginata.
�
Mark
�
�

Thanks!

Andres

messages.subject: Yari and Naginata
messages.msgSnippet: Nihonto People, I haven t seen a whole lot of books on Yari and/or Naginata in English, so even though it was a bit pricy, I purchased Roald and Susan
messages.messageBody:
Nihonto People,

I haven't seen a whole lot of books on Yari and/or Naginata in
English, so even though it was a bit pricy, I purchased Roald and
Susan Knutsen's book (http://tinyurl.com/yxlhuj). I just finished it.
I am very impressed and sorry I did not purchase it earlier. The
concise yet informative text plus the wealth of drawings and plates
was well worth the price.

If there's anyone else out there interested in the subject and that
has been on the fence about this great book because of the price tag,
well, stop considering it and buy it. Give it to yourself for
Christmas. You won't regret it.

And if Roald and Susan subscribe to these lists (or someone who knows
them does) please receive a big thank you from me... This book will
be a permanent part of my reference library.

Anyone have any other books on Yari and/or Naginata they want to
recommend? I'm thirsty for more knowledge now.

Thanks!

Andres
